sect1.title: GUI Menu and Tool Bars
sect1.para: This section describes the commands available in the GUI menus and tool bar.

sect2.title: File Menu
sect2.para: The File menu provides standard file management options, and in addition allows you to import and export libraries and manage your object files with the revision control system.

row.entry: Opens a "file" dialog that lets you name your new object file. Object file names end with ".fwb". In general, you should create a new directory for your object files.
Opens a standard "file" dialog that lets you select an existing file. The file dialog, by default, only looks for files that end in ".fwb".
Contains a submenu listing recently opened object files.
Opens a "file" dialog that lets you save the object file under a new name.
Closes the current object file, but does not exit the program.
Opens a dialog indicating properties of the current file, including revision control information (if applicable.) (Program preferences are in the Edit menu.)
This menu item adds the object file to reversion control. See for a detailed explanation.
Commits current changes to RCS. (This option is grayed out if the file has not already been added to RCS.) See for a detailed explanation.
Discards current changes. (This option is grayed out if the file has not already been added to RCS.) See for a detailed explanation.
Allows you to import an existing policy into Firewall Builder. See for a deta iled explanation.
Lets you import an Object Library. (See Export Library.)

Brings up a dialog that lets you select which Object Library you wish to export to a ".fwl" file. Once a library is exported, you can import it into another instantiation of Firewall Builder. This is particularly useful in Enterprise settings that have multiple Firewall Builder workstations and administrators.

sect2.title: Edit Menu
sect2.para: The Edit options are standard for GUI-based tools. Preferences for Firewall Builder are described in .

sect2.title: View Menu
sect2.para: The View menu lets you turn on or off various display panes.

row.entry: If checked, the object tree is displayed
Displays the object editor. You can also display this panel by double-clicking an object.
Displays the undo history. You can undo several changes by clicking on the last change you want to keep. With th e next change, all changes after the current one are removed from the undo history.

sect2.title: Object Menu
sect2.para: The Object menu lets you create a new object, find occurrences of an object (including doing replaces), lock an object to prevent accidental changes, and unlock an object when you need to edit it.

row.entry: Opens a menu of all possible object types. Select one to create a new object of that type. describes how to create objects.
Opens the Find object dialog, which also provides search and replace functions. explains how to use this dialog.

Makes the selected object read-only, which prevents accidental modification. An object that is locked has a little padlock for its icon. In this example, the eth0 interface of test server is locked. Locking the eth0 interface object also renders read-only the address objects associated with the interface. (Note that the test server object, located "above" eth0 in the hierarchy, is still editable.)
Locked Object

Unlocks the selected object. The object becomes editable, and the objects associated with it become editable as well, unless they have their own locks.
Unlocked Object

sect2.title: Rules Menu
sect2.para: The Rules menu lets you add, delete, and rearrange rules and rule groups in a policy. In addition, the Rules menu lets you compile an individual rule or an entire policy or install an entire policy. The menu is context-sensitive, so not all options are visible at all times. See for details.

sect2.title: Tools Menu
sect2.para: The Tools menu provides access to useful tools.

row.entry: Find Conflicting Objects in Two Files

Launches a tool that lets you specify two object files (.fwb) or two library files (.fwl). The tool then looks for objects that have the same ID, but different characteristics. This kind of conflict would cause a problem if you wanted to merge the files.
Launches a wizard that lets you populate many objects automatically using an SNMP crawl, an existing "hosts" file, or the import of an existing firewall policy. explains the tool.

sect2.title: Window Menu
sect2.para: The Window menu provides controls for selecting and rearranging object file windows. This feature works similarly to Window menus in most GUIs.

sect2.title: Help Menu
sect2.para: The Help menu provides access to help resources, information about the current version of Firewall Builder, and a dialog with debugging information.

sect2.title: Object Context Menu
sect2.para: The Context Menu for a particular object provides a short-cut to menu commands for that object. Right-cl ick an object's label to bring up a menu of the following functions:

row.entry: Opens the Editor dialog for that object. (You can achieve the same result by double-clicking the object.)

Places a copy of the object into the specified library. (If no user-created libraries exist, then Firewall Builder puts the object in the User tree by default.) The new object has the same name as the original object, unless that object name is already in use in that tree. If so, a "-1" is appended to the object name.
Copies an object onto the clipboard.
Copies an object onto the clipboard and removes it from the tree.
Puts a copy of the object on the clipboard into a tree or into the policy, depending on where the mouse is when you click.
Deletes an object without making a copy on the clipboard. If the Deleted Objects tree has been enabled, the object shows up there.

entry.para: Brings up a Find/Find-and-Replace panel, which is another tab in the object dialog. Click Next in the panel to see all instances of the object boxed in red.

To do a Search and Replace, drag another object into the Replace object box, specify a scope for the replacement using the pull-down menu, and then use the Replace All, Replace, Replace & Find, and Next buttons.

row.entry: Scans the whole tree, including all groups and policies of all firewalls, looking for references to the object. When finished, the program shows a pop-up dialog with icons corresponding to groups and firewalls using the object. Double-clicking an icon opens the corresponding object in the main window.
Lock makes an object read-only, which prevents accidental modification. Unlock places the object back into read/write mode.

sect2.para: The pop-up menu can also have items to add interface and address objects, depending on the type of object that was clicked.

In addition, the right-click context menu on policy rules has a selection for Compile Rule. Sele cting this option compiles the rule and displays the output in the Output tab of the Editor dialog. See for details on compiling a single rule and viewing the results in the Output tab.

sect2.title: Tool Bar
sect2.para: The Tool Bar has buttons for commonly used functions:

row.entry: Opens a standard "file" dialog that lets you select an existing file. The file dialog, by default, only looks for files that end in ".fwb".
Opens the Find object dialog, which also provides search-and-replace functions. explains how to use this dialog.
Opens the compile wizard for all firewalls in the current object file. The compile button on an individual file opens the compile dialog for just the selected firewall. explains this in more detail.

Opens the compile/install wizard for all firewalls in the current object file. The compile/install button on an individual file opens the compile /install dialog for just the selected firewall. explains this in more detail.
